name: useTimer hook
description:
Create src/hooks/useTimer.ts — a self-contained timer hook for puzzle solve timing.

## What
Standalone React hook that tracks elapsed time with start/stop/reset controls. Used by usePuzzle to time puzzle solves. Outputs both raw milliseconds and formatted MM:SS string.

## API

```typescript
interface UseTimerReturn {
  elapsedMs: number;
  formatted: string;       // "01:23" format
  isRunning: boolean;
  start: () => void;
  stop: () => void;
  reset: () => void;
}

function useTimer(): UseTimerReturn;
```

## Implementation
- Use useRef to store start timestamp and accumulated time
- Use useState for elapsedMs (triggers re-render on tick)
- Use useRef for the interval ID
- Tick interval: ~100ms (smooth enough for MM:SS display, not wasteful)
- start(): record Date.now() as start, begin interval
- stop(): add elapsed since start to accumulated, clear interval
- reset(): clear accumulated, clear interval, set elapsedMs to 0
- formatted: derive MM:SS from elapsedMs using padStart
- Cleanup: clear interval on unmount (useEffect return)

## Edge Cases
- Calling start() when already running: no-op
- Calling stop() when already stopped: no-op
- Calling reset() while running: stops and resets

## Done When
- Hook returns correct elapsed time
- MM:SS format is correct (e.g., 83 seconds → "01:23")
- start/stop/reset work correctly
- No memory leaks (interval cleared on unmount)
- No any types
result: Created src/lib/timer.ts with PuzzleTimer class and src/hooks/useTimer.ts React hook. PuzzleTimer: start/stop/reset/dispose lifecycle, elapsedMs getter with accumulated+running delta, onTick callback at 100ms intervals, static formatTime(ms) for MM:SS. useTimer hook: thin React wrapper with useRef for PuzzleTimer, useState for elapsedMs driving re-renders, cleanup on unmount. 16 tests passing covering start/stop, accumulation, idempotency, reset, tick callbacks, dispose, formatTime edge cases. TypeScript strict clean, no any types.

name: Info panel, controls, and move list
description:
Build the side panel UI: puzzle info, timer display, analysis lines, move list, and action buttons.

## What
Create the right-side panel (desktop) / bottom section (mobile) containing all non-board UI: puzzle metadata, timer, Stockfish analysis lines, recorded move list, and the Next/Stats/Settings buttons. This is the 'command center' of the puzzle experience.

## Design Reference
- Desktop (desktop.png): Panel to the right of the board with puzzle info at top, timer, analysis section, moves section, and bottom action bar
- Mobile (mobile.png): Info below board with tabbed Analysis/Moves sections

## Implementation

### 1. PuzzleInfo Component (src/components/PuzzleInfo.tsx)
- Large puzzle number: '42' with '/ 4462' in smaller text
- Puzzle type in accent color: 'Mate in 2' (gold/yellow per screenshots)
- Side to move: '• White to move' (or status text: 'Solved ✓' / 'Failed')
- Status changes color: green for solved, red for failed

### 2. Timer Component (src/components/Timer.tsx)
- Large monospace MM:SS display (01:23 format per screenshots)
- 'ELAPSED' label below during play
- On solve: timer turns green, label changes to 'SOLVE TIME'
- On fail+complete: timer turns red, label changes to 'TIME'
- Timer size increases in complete states (celebration/emphasis per states_2.png)

### 3. Analysis Panel
- Header: 'ANALYSIS' with ON/OFF toggle (green 'ON' text per desktop.png)
- Show top 2 Stockfish evaluation lines:
  - Format: '#2 Qxg7+ Kxg7 Bxf6#' with depth indicator (d32)
  - Mate scores in green (#2), centipawn scores in yellow (+8.2)

### 4. Move List

- Numbered move pairs: '1. Qxg7+ Kxg7' (user move, opponent response)
- Placeholder for next move: dashed border 'Your move...' (per desktop.png)

- Wrong moves: red text with strikethrough (e.g., 'Bf4?' per states screenshots)

### 5. Action Bar (bottom)

- 'Stats' button (center)
- 'Next →' button (rightmost)
  - Disabled/muted during active play
  - Enabled + highlighted (green) after checkmate
  - Full-width on mobile (per mobile.png)

### 6. Tabbed Layout (Mobile)
- 'ANALYSIS' and 'MOVES' as tab headers (per mobile.png)
- Default to MOVES tab
- Active tab has underline/highlight indicator
- Tab content scrollable if moves exceed visible area

- Move list records and displays all moves with correct annotations

name: Stockfish engine integration
description:
Integrate Stockfish WASM engine running in a Web Worker for move validation and opponent play.

## What
Create the Stockfish service layer that powers two critical flows: (1) validating whether the user's move maintains a forced mate, and (2) playing the opponent's best defense after a correct user move.

## Why
The engine is central to the puzzle experience. It determines correctness by checking if the user's move still leads to mate in N moves, and it plays realistic opponent responses (best defense) rather than scripted lines.

## Implementation

### 1. Stockfish Worker (src/lib/stockfish.ts)
- Load stockfish WASM ('lite' variant ~7MB for mobile perf) in a Web Worker
- UCI protocol initialization: send 'uci', wait for 'uciok', send 'isready', wait for 'readyok'
- Create a promise-based API wrapping the postMessage/onmessage pattern
- Key methods:
  - analyze(fen, depth): returns {bestMove, score, mateIn}
  - getBestMove(fen): returns the best move string
  - stop(): cancel ongoing analysis
  - isReady(): check engine state

### 2. UCI Response Parsing
- Parse 'bestmove e2e4' responses
- Parse 'info depth N score mate M' for mate detection
- Parse 'info depth N score cp C' for centipawn evaluation
- Extract PV (principal variation) lines for the analysis display

### 3. useStockfish Hook (src/hooks/useStockfish.ts)
- Manages engine lifecycle (init, ready state, cleanup on unmount)
- Exposes: validateMove(fen, requiredMateIn) → {isCorrect, bestMove, evaluation}
- Exposes: getOpponentMove(fen) → bestMove string
- Loading state while engine initializes
- Error handling for WASM load failures (fallback to non-engine mode)

### 4. Move Validation Logic
- After user moves, send new FEN to engine at depth 15
- Check if 'score mate N' exists where N ≤ required moves remaining
- If mate found → move is correct
- If no forced mate → move is incorrect, puzzle marked failed
- Edge case: user delivers checkmate directly (no engine needed, chess.js detects it)

## Done When
- Engine loads in Web Worker without blocking main thread
- analyze() returns correct mate evaluations for known positions
- Opponent best-move responses are reasonable (defends well)
- Engine gracefully handles rapid position changes (stop previous analysis)
- Fallback mode works when engine fails to load
result:
Stockfish engine integration complete. All 3 subtasks done.

## Summary
Integrated Stockfish WASM (Chess.com's lite-single-threaded build, ~7MB) running in a Web Worker for move validation and opponent play. The PuzzleEngine uses a pluggable PuzzleStrategy pattern with an always-async unified code path (Option B).

## Files changed/created
- package.json: added stockfish dependency + copy-stockfish/postinstall scripts
- .gitignore: added public/stockfish/
- public/stockfish/: stockfish-18-lite-single.js + .wasm (auto-copied from node_modules)
- src/types/index.ts: MoveValidationResult, ValidateMoveFn, GetOpponentMoveFn, PuzzleStrategy
- src/lib/stockfish.ts: StockfishEngine class, UCI parsing, uciToParsedMove
- src/lib/puzzle-engine.ts: refactored to async makeMove() with PuzzleStrategy injection
- src/hooks/useStockfish.ts: engine lifecycle management, createEngineStrategy
- src/hooks/usePuzzle.ts: strategy selection based on settings.engineEnabled + engine readiness
- src/lib/__tests__/stockfish.test.ts: 19 tests for UCI parsing

## Key behaviors
- Engine enabled: validates moves via Stockfish mate-in-N analysis, opponent plays best defense
- Engine disabled: validates against stored solution, user plays both sides after failure
- Post-failure (engine): Stockfish continues playing opponent, user explores position
- Graceful fallback: if engine fails to load, falls back to solution-based mode
- tsc clean, 102 tests passing

name: Stockfish UCI service class with response parsing and promise API
description:
Create src/lib/stockfish.ts — the core Stockfish engine service with UCI protocol handling.

## What
A TypeScript class that manages a Stockfish Web Worker, handles UCI protocol communication, parses engine output, and exposes a clean promise-based API for analysis. This is the bridge between raw UCI text protocol and typed TypeScript.

## API

```typescript
interface AnalysisResult {
  bestMove: string;           // UCI format: "e2e4"
  mateIn: number | null;      // Positive = side to move mates in N, negative = opponent mates
  cpScore: number | null;     // Centipawn score (when no mate found)
  pv: string[];               // Principal variation moves in UCI format
  depth: number;              // Depth reached
}

class StockfishEngine {
  init(): Promise<void>;                              // Load worker + UCI handshake
  analyze(fen: string, depth?: number): Promise<AnalysisResult>;  // Full analysis
  stop(): void;                                       // Cancel ongoing analysis
  dispose(): void;                                    // Terminate worker
  readonly isReady: boolean;                          // Engine state
}
```

## Implementation

### 1. Worker Lifecycle
- Constructor takes the path to the stockfish JS file (default: '/stockfish/stockfish-nnue-17.1-lite-single-[hash].js')
- `init()`: create Worker, send 'uci', wait for 'uciok', send 'isready', wait for 'readyok'
- `dispose()`: send 'quit', terminate worker
- Handle Worker creation errors gracefully (WASM not supported, file not found)

### 2. UCI Communication Layer
- Internal message queue/promise pattern: send command → collect output lines → resolve when terminal response received
- Terminal responses: 'uciok' (for 'uci'), 'readyok' (for 'isready'), 'bestmove ...' (for 'go')
- Stream 'info' lines during analysis to capture the best evaluation seen

### 3. UCI Response Parsing (pure functions, export for testing)
- `parseBestMove(line: string)`: extract move from 'bestmove e2e4 ponder f7f5'
- `parseInfoLine(line: string)`: extract depth, score (mate/cp), pv from 'info depth 15 seldepth 20 score mate 2 pv e2e4 e7e5 d1h5'
- Score types: 'score mate N' (forced mate in N full moves) vs 'score cp C' (centipawn advantage)
- PV extraction: the 'pv' token followed by move list until end of line
- Handle edge cases: 'bestmove (none)', missing score, incomplete info lines

### 4. analyze() Method
- Stop any ongoing analysis first (send 'stop' if busy)
- Send 'position fen <fen>'
- Send 'go depth <depth>' (default 15)
- Collect info lines, track the highest-depth result with score
- Resolve promise when 'bestmove' line arrives
- Return the best AnalysisResult seen

### 5. Rapid Position Changes
- If analyze() is called while a previous analysis is running, stop the old one first
- Use an analysis ID or AbortController pattern to discard stale results
- The 'stop' UCI command makes the engine emit 'bestmove' immediately

## Tests (src/lib/__tests__/stockfish.test.ts)
Test the pure parsing functions (no Worker needed):
- parseBestMove: standard move, with ponder, '(none)' edge case
- parseInfoLine: mate score, cp score, with PV, without PV, various depths
- parseInfoLine: negative mate scores (opponent mates), zero cp
- Edge cases: empty lines, malformed input

## Done When
- StockfishEngine can init(), analyze(), stop(), dispose()
- analyze() returns correct AnalysisResult for known positions
- Rapid stop+re-analyze doesn't cause stale results
- Pure parsing functions have comprehensive tests
- No 'any' types, strict TypeScript
result:
Created src/lib/stockfish.ts with StockfishEngine class and UCI protocol handling.

## StockfishEngine class
- Worker lifecycle: init() with UCI handshake (uci→uciok, isready→readyok), dispose() with worker termination
- analyze(fen, depth=15): promise-based analysis returning AnalysisResult {bestMove, score, pv, depth}
- Handles rapid position changes: stop previous analysis before starting new, generation-based stale result rejection
- State machine: idle→initializing→ready→analyzing→disposed

## Pure parsing functions (exported, tested)
- parseBestMove: extracts move from 'bestmove e2e4 ponder f7f5', handles '(none)', returns undefined for non-bestmove lines
- parseInfoLine: extracts depth, score (mate/cp), and PV from info lines
- uciToParsedMove: converts UCI format "e2e4"/"a7a8q" to typed ParsedMove

## Tests
19 tests passing: parseBestMove (5), parseInfoLine (8), uciToParsedMove (4), plus mate score sign tests.
No any types, strict TypeScript clean.

name: usePuzzle state machine hook
description:
Create src/hooks/usePuzzle.ts — the core state machine orchestrating the puzzle experience.

## What
The brain of the app. Manages the full puzzle lifecycle: loading a puzzle, tracking game phase, processing user moves, playing opponent responses (engine-disabled fallback mode first), recording move history, and persisting results.

## API

```typescript
interface MoveRecord {
  moveNumber: number;
  userMove: { san: string; correct: boolean };
  opponentMove?: { san: string };
}

interface UsePuzzleReturn {
  phase: GamePhase;
  fen: string;
  orientation: "white" | "black";
  turnColor: "white" | "black";
  dests: Map<string, string[]>;
  lastMove: [string, string] | undefined;
  isFailed: boolean;
  moveHistory: MoveRecord[];
  puzzleData: PuzzleData | null;
  elapsedMs: number;
  formattedTime: string;
  makeMove: (from: string, to: string, promotion?: string) => void;
  nextPuzzle: () => void;
}
```

## State Machine Implementation

### Phase Transitions
1. LOADING: Load puzzle by ID from puzzles array, parse FEN into chess.js, compute legal dests, determine orientation → PLAYING (start timer)
2. PLAYING: User's turn. On makeMove():
   - Apply move to chess.js instance
   - If chess.isCheckmate() → COMPLETE (stop timer, record success/fail)
   - Else validate move:
     - Engine-disabled: compare to solution sequence
     - If correct + not checkmate → OPPONENT_TURN
     - If incorrect → mark isFailed=true, still allow play → stay in PLAYING
3. VALIDATING: (reserved for engine mode — skip for now, engine-disabled goes directly)
4. OPPONENT_TURN: 
   - Engine-disabled: play next move from solution sequence
   - Apply opponent move to chess.js, update fen + lastMove + dests
   - Brief delay (~400ms) for animation feel
   - → PLAYING
5. COMPLETE: Checkmate delivered.
   - Save to localStorage: status = isFailed ? "fail" : "success", timeMs
   - On nextPuzzle(): increment currentPuzzleId, → LOADING

### Engine-Disabled Fallback (implement first)
The solution moves field contains alternating user/opponent moves:
- "f6-g7" (Mate in One: just the user's mating move)
- "d1-h5;g6-h5;f3-f7" (Mate in Two: user, opponent, user)
- Odd-indexed moves (0, 2, 4...) = user moves, even-indexed (1, 3, 5...) = opponent moves

Validation: compare user's move (from/to/promotion) against the expected solution move at the current index. If mismatch → mark failed. The user can still continue playing freely after failure (chess.js validates legality).

After a correct user move that's not checkmate: auto-play the opponent's move from the solution.

After failure: the user plays freely — all subsequent moves are validated only by chess.js legality (not against solution). The puzzle still continues until checkmate is delivered somehow.

### Move History
- Record each move pair: { moveNumber, userMove: { san, correct }, opponentMove?: { san } }
- Correct moves: correct=true (matches solution or post-failure legal play)
- Wrong moves: correct=false (first deviation from solution)
- Used by the UI to render the move list with red strikethrough for wrong moves

### Integration Points
- useAppState: updatePuzzle() for persistence, setCurrentPuzzleId() for navigation
- useTimer: start/stop/reset on phase transitions
- chess.ts: loadFen, makeMove, getLegalDests, isCheckmate
- puzzles.ts: parseMoves for solution sequence

## Done When
- Full puzzle lifecycle works in engine-disabled mode: load → play → checkmate → next
- Correct moves advance through solution sequence
- Incorrect moves mark puzzle failed, user can keep playing
- Opponent auto-plays from solution after correct moves
- Move history records all moves with correct/incorrect annotation
- Timer runs during play, stops on completion
- Puzzle result persists to localStorage
- Next puzzle advances correctly
- No any types
result: Created src/lib/puzzle-engine.ts with PuzzleEngine class and src/hooks/usePuzzle.ts hook. PuzzleEngine manages state machine (loading/playing/opponent_turn/complete), chess.js instance, solution tracking, move validation (engine-disabled fallback), move history with correct/incorrect annotation, and auto-opponent play with 400ms delay. Post-failure: user plays both sides freely. usePuzzle hook wraps PuzzleEngine + useTimer + useAppState, handles puzzle loading, timer lifecycle (start on play, stop on complete), persistence (saves status/time/attempts), and nextPuzzle navigation. TypeScript strict clean.

name: Zugzwang — Chess Puzzle Trainer
description:
# Zugzwang — Chess Puzzle Trainer

## Overview

Zugzwang is a web-based chess puzzle trainer featuring 4,462 puzzles from the Susan Polgar collection. Users progress linearly through puzzles, playing out full checkmate sequences against Stockfish's best defense.

---

## Core Experience

### Puzzle Flow

1. User loads puzzle (FEN position displayed on board)
2. Prompt shows "White to move" / "Black to move" and puzzle type ("Mate in 2")
3. User makes a move
4. **If correct**: Stockfish plays best defense, user continues until checkmate
5. **If incorrect**: Puzzle marked as **failed**, but user can continue playing to understand the position
6. **On checkmate**: Puzzle complete; subtle success indicator shown only if solved correctly
7. User clicks "Next" to advance

### Validation Logic

- **Engine enabled**: Stockfish analyzes position to verify user's move leads to mate in required moves
- **Engine disabled**: Validate against stored solution moves from JSON (first move only, then auto-play sequence)

### Feedback Philosophy

- Minimal, non-intrusive
- Success: subtle visual confirmation (e.g., brief green glow, soft sound)
- Failure: no explicit "wrong" message—puzzle silently marked failed, user discovers why through continued play

---

## Data Source

**Repository**: https://github.com/denialromeo/4462-chess-problems

**JSON structure**:
```json
{
  "problemid": 1,
  "first": "White to Move",
  "type": "Mate in One",
  "fen": "3q1rk1/5pbp/5Qp1/8/8/2B5/5PPP/6K1 w - - 0 1",
  "moves": "f6-g7"
}
```

**Fields**:
- `problemid`: Sequential ID (1–4462)
- `first`: Who moves first
- `type`: Puzzle type (Mate in One, Mate in Two, etc.)
- `fen`: Board position in FEN notation
- `moves`: Solution moves in `from-to` format (e.g., `f6-g7`, `f7-f8q` for promotion)

---

## Tech Stack

| Layer | Technology | Purpose |
|-------|------------|---------|
| Framework | React 18+ | UI components |
| Build | Vite | Fast dev/build |
| Language | TypeScript | Type safety |
| Board UI | @lichess-org/chessground | Chess board rendering, drag/drop, touch |
| Chess Logic | chess.js | Move validation, FEN parsing, game state |
| Engine | stockfish (npm) | WASM Stockfish for move validation & opponent play |
| Hosting | Vercel | Free static hosting |
| Persistence | localStorage | Progress, stats |

### Key Libraries

**@lichess-org/chessground**
- Lichess's production chess UI
- 10KB gzipped, no dependencies
- Mobile/touch ready
- GPL-3.0 license

**chess.js**
- Move generation and validation
- FEN/PGN parsing
- Game state management (check, checkmate, draw)

**stockfish (npm)**
- Chess.com's WASM build
- Use "lite" variant (~7MB) for mobile performance
- Runs in Web Worker

---

## Persistence (localStorage)

### Schema

```typescript
interface PuzzleState {
  status: 'unattempted' | 'success' | 'fail';
  timeMs: number | null;      // Time to solve (ms)
  attempts: number;           // Number of attempts
}

interface AppState {
  currentPuzzleId: number;    // 1-indexed
  puzzles: Record<number, PuzzleState>;
  settings: {
    engineEnabled: boolean;
  };
}
```

### Derived Stats (computed on read)

- Total puzzles attempted
- Total solved correctly
- Success rate (%)
- Average solve time
- Current puzzle position (e.g., "42 / 4462")

---

## UI Components

### Main View (Single Page)

See images in the folder
- @desktop.png
- @mobile.png

Various states (feedback)
- @states_1.png
- @states_2.png

### Components

1. **PuzzleInfo**
   - Puzzle number + total ("42 / 4462")
   - Puzzle type ("Mate in 2")
   - Who moves ("White to move")

2. **ChessBoard**
   - Chessground instance
   - Auto-orients based on `first` field (white at bottom if white to move)
   - Legal move highlighting
   - Drag/drop + click-click move input

3. **Timer**
   - Starts when puzzle loads
   - Stops on checkmate
   - Displays MM:SS format

4. **NextButton**
   - Hidden during active puzzle
   - Appears after checkmate
   - Advances to next puzzle

5. **SettingsModal**
   - Engine on/off toggle
   - (Future: board theme, sound, etc.)

6. **StatsView**
   - Accessible via icon/link
   - Shows aggregate statistics
   - Could be modal or slide-out panel

### Responsive Behavior

- **Desktop**: Board ~500-600px, info beside or above
- **Tablet**: Board fills width with padding, info above
- **Mobile**: Board fills width, info stacked above, controls below

---

## Stockfish Integration

### Initialization

```typescript
// Load engine in Web Worker
const stockfish = new Worker('stockfish.js');

stockfish.onmessage = (e) => {
  // Parse UCI responses
};

stockfish.postMessage('uci');
stockfish.postMessage('isready');
```

### Move Validation Flow

1. User makes move
2. Apply move to chess.js board
3. Send position to Stockfish: `position fen <new_fen>`
4. Request analysis: `go depth 15`
5. Parse `bestmove` and `score mate N` from output
6. If mate in ≤ required moves exists → move is correct
7. If no forced mate → move is incorrect (mark puzzle failed)

### Opponent Response

1. After valid user move (not checkmate)
2. Stockfish already computed best defense
3. Apply best move to board
4. Animate piece movement
5. User's turn again

### Fallback (Engine Disabled)

- Validate first move against `moves` field in JSON
- Auto-play opponent responses from solution
- Less flexible but works offline/low-power devices

---

## Move Format Conversion

The JSON uses `from-to` format (e.g., `f6-g7`). Need to convert:

```typescript
function parseMove(move: string): { from: string; to: string; promotion?: string } {
  // "f6-g7" → { from: "f6", to: "g7" }
  // "f7-f8q" → { from: "f7", to: "f8", promotion: "q" }
  const [from, toRaw] = move.split('-');
  const promotion = toRaw.length > 2 ? toRaw[2] : undefined;
  const to = toRaw.slice(0, 2);
  return { from, to, promotion };
}
```

---

## State Machine

```
┌──────────────┐
│   LOADING    │ ← Initial state, loading puzzle data
└──────┬───────┘
       │
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│   PLAYING    │ ← User's turn, timer running
└──────┬───────┘
       │ User moves
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│  VALIDATING  │ ← Engine analyzing move
└──────┬───────┘
       │
       ├─── Valid + Checkmate ───▶ COMPLETE (success)
       │
       ├─── Valid + Not Mate ───▶ OPPONENT_TURN
       │
       └─── Invalid ───▶ PLAYING (puzzle marked failed)

┌──────────────┐
│OPPONENT_TURN │ ← Stockfish plays, animating
└──────┬───────┘
       │
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│   PLAYING    │
└──────────────┘

┌──────────────┐
│   COMPLETE   │ ← Checkmate delivered
└──────┬───────┘
       │ User clicks Next
       ▼
┌──────────────┐
│   LOADING    │ ← Load next puzzle
└──────────────┘
```

---

## File Structure

```
zugzwang/
├── public/
│   └── problems.json          # Puzzle data (fetched at runtime or bundled)
├── src/
│   ├── main.tsx               # Entry point
│   ├── App.tsx                # Main app component
│   ├── components/
│   │   ├── Board.tsx          # Chessground wrapper
│   │   ├── PuzzleInfo.tsx     # Puzzle metadata display
│   │   ├── Timer.tsx          # Solve timer
│   │   ├── NextButton.tsx     # Navigation
│   │   ├── Settings.tsx       # Settings modal
│   │   └── Stats.tsx          # Statistics view
│   ├── hooks/
│   │   ├── useStockfish.ts    # Engine management
│   │   ├── usePuzzle.ts       # Puzzle state management
│   │   ├── useTimer.ts        # Timer logic
│   │   └── useLocalStorage.ts # Persistence
│   ├── lib/
│   │   ├── chess.ts           # chess.js wrapper utilities
│   │   ├── stockfish.ts       # Stockfish UCI communication
│   │   └── puzzles.ts         # Puzzle data loading/parsing
│   ├── types/
│   │   └── index.ts           # TypeScript interfaces
│   └── styles/
│       ├── chessground.css    # Chessground base styles
│       └── app.css            # App styles
├── index.html
├── package.json
├── tsconfig.json
├── vite.config.ts
└── README.md
```

---

## Future Considerations (Out of Scope)

- User accounts / cloud sync
- Leaderboards
- Spaced repetition for failed puzzles
- Puzzle filtering by type/difficulty
- Custom puzzle sets
- Board themes / piece sets
- Sound effects
- Keyboard shortcuts
- Share puzzle links

---

## Open Questions

1. **Bundle vs fetch puzzles**: Include `problems.json` in bundle (~500KB) or fetch at runtime?
   - Recommendation: Bundle for offline capability and faster initial load

2. **Stockfish depth**: What analysis depth for validation?
   - Recommendation: depth 15 (fast enough, accurate for mate puzzles)

3. **Success animation**: What exactly? Options:
   - Brief green border glow
   - Checkmark icon
   - Confetti (maybe too much)
   - Subtle sound

---

## License

GPL-3.0 (required by Chessground dependency)

name: Feedback states and visual polish
description:
Implement the four visual feedback states: correct move, incorrect move, puzzle solved, and failed-but-completed.

## What
Add the visual feedback layer that communicates puzzle outcomes through board border glows, toast messages, color changes, and move annotations. This is what makes the puzzle experience feel responsive and satisfying.

## Design Reference
- states_1.png: Correct move (green glow + toast) and Incorrect move (red glow + toast)
- states_2.png: Puzzle Solved (green border, green timer) and Failed but Completed (red border, red timer)
- mobile.png: Same states adapted to mobile layout

## Implementation

### 1. Board Glow / Border Feedback
- Correct move: board border briefly pulses green, then returns to default
- Incorrect move: board border briefly pulses red, then persists subtly
- Puzzle solved (complete + no failures): board has persistent green border
- Failed but completed: board has persistent red border
- CSS transitions for smooth glow animation (~500ms pulse)

### 2. Toast Notifications
- Correct move: '✓ Correct! Opponent plays...' in green-bordered toast (per states_1.png)
- Incorrect move: '✗ Not the best move. Keep playing to explore.' in red-bordered toast
- Toasts appear between timer and move list
- Auto-dismiss after ~2-3 seconds, or on next action
- Minimal animation (fade in/out)

### 3. Puzzle Complete States (per states_2.png)
**Solved successfully:**
- PuzzleInfo status: 'Solved ✓' in green (replaces 'White to move')
- Timer: larger size, green color, label 'SOLVE TIME'
- Analysis shows '#0 Checkmate'
- All moves in green
- Next button highlighted green

**Failed but completed (reached checkmate after wrong move):**
- PuzzleInfo status: 'Failed' in red
- Timer: larger size, red color, label 'TIME'
- Analysis shows '#0 Checkmate'
- Wrong moves in red with strikethrough, correct moves in default
- Next button highlighted green

### 4. Move Annotations in Move List
- Correct user moves: green text (or default white)
- Wrong user moves: red text, strikethrough, '?' annotation (e.g., 'Bf4?')
- Checkmate move: '#' suffix (e.g., 'Bxf6#')
- Check move: '+' suffix (e.g., 'Qxg7+')

### 5. Transition Animations
- State transitions should feel smooth, not jarring
- Board border color changes with CSS transition
- Timer color/size change with transition
- Toast fade in (200ms) and fade out (300ms)
- Next button enable animation (opacity/color transition)

## Done When
- Correct move shows green board pulse + toast message
- Incorrect move shows red board pulse + toast + marks puzzle failed
- Solved puzzle shows persistent green border, green timer, 'Solved ✓'
- Failed-but-completed shows persistent red border, red timer, 'Failed'
- Wrong moves display as red strikethrough in move list
- All transitions are smooth (no visual jumps)
- Feedback matches the states_1.png and states_2.png designs

name: Install stockfish package and configure Vite for WASM Web Worker
description:
Install the stockfish npm package and configure the project so the engine loads in a Web Worker.

## What
Set up the stockfish npm package (v17.1, Chess.com's WASM build) and make the **lite single-threaded** variant available as a static asset that can be loaded in a Web Worker.

## Why
The lite-single-threaded variant (~7MB) is the right choice: small enough for mobile, no SharedArrayBuffer/COOP/COEP header requirements (works on all modern browsers without special server config).

## Implementation

### 1. Install package
- `npm install stockfish`
- This pulls in ~183MB unpacked (all variants); we only serve the lite-single-threaded files

### 2. Copy engine files to public/
- Copy the lite-single-threaded JS + WASM files from `node_modules/stockfish/src/` to `public/stockfish/`
  - Files match pattern: `stockfish-nnue-17.1-lite-single-*.js` and `stockfish-nnue-17.1-lite-single-*.wasm`
- Add a postinstall or build script to automate this copy (so it survives clean installs)
- Add `public/stockfish/` to .gitignore (derived files)

### 3. Vite configuration
- Ensure Vite serves `.wasm` files with correct `Content-Type: application/wasm` (Vite does this by default, but verify)
- No COOP/COEP headers needed for single-threaded variant
- Verify the Worker JS file can locate its companion .wasm file (they need to be in the same directory)

### 4. Verification
- Create a minimal test: `new Worker('/stockfish/stockfish-nnue-17.1-lite-single-[hash].js')` → send 'uci' → receive 'uciok'
- Verify in both `npm run dev` and `npm run build && npm run preview`
- Check browser console for any WASM loading errors

## Done When
- `npm install` + build script copies engine files to public/stockfish/
- A Web Worker can be instantiated pointing to the lite-single-threaded JS file
- Worker responds to 'uci' with 'uciok' and 'isready' with 'readyok'
- Works in both dev and production builds
- No console errors related to WASM loading or MIME types

name: useStockfish hook + PuzzleEngine integration for engine-enabled mode
description:
Wire Stockfish into the existing puzzle state machine using the always-async unified path (Option B).

## What
Create the useStockfish React hook for engine lifecycle management, then refactor PuzzleEngine so makeMove() is always async — both solution-based and engine-based validation go through the same code path via a pluggable validation strategy.

## Design Decision: Option B (Always-Async Unified Path)
- makeMove() is always async. Both modes pass through the `validating` phase.
- Solution-based validation wraps in Promise.resolve() (~0ms, invisible to user/React).
- Engine-based validation awaits Stockfish analysis (~50-300ms, masked by animation).
- One code path = simpler tests, fewer bugs, less maintenance.

## Key Behavior
### Post-Failure Free Play
- If user gets a move wrong (any puzzle type), the puzzle is marked failed BUT:
  - Stockfish plays its best response to whatever the user played
  - User can keep playing both sides freely until checkmate
  - This lets users explore and understand the position
- For mate-in-1: wrong move → failed → Stockfish responds → user keeps playing until mate
- For mate-in-2: correct first move → Stockfish plays best defense → user finds mating move

### Validation Strategy Interface
```typescript
interface MoveValidationResult {
  isCorrect: boolean;
  opponentMove: string | null;  // UCI format "e2e4" or null if checkmate/no response
}

type ValidateMoveFn = (fen: string, remainingMateDepth: number) => Promise<MoveValidationResult>;
```

Two implementations:
1. **Solution-based**: compares against solution[], returns opponent from solution[]. Wrapped in Promise.resolve().
2. **Engine-based**: calls StockfishEngine.analyze(), checks mate score, returns bestMove for opponent.

PuzzleEngine accepts a ValidateMoveFn — doesn't know or care which implementation.

## Implementation

### 1. useStockfish Hook (src/hooks/useStockfish.ts)
- On mount: create StockfishEngine, call init()
- Track loading/ready/error states
- On unmount: dispose engine
- Expose isReady, isLoading, error for UI

### 2. Refactor PuzzleEngine (src/lib/puzzle-engine.ts)
- makeMove() becomes async (returns Promise<void>)
- Always enters VALIDATING after applying move to chess.js
- Calls the injected ValidateMoveFn
- On result: transitions based on isCorrect + checkmate detection
- Post-failure: Stockfish still plays opponent moves (best defense), user plays freely
- Opponent move comes from validation result, not hardcoded solution index

### 3. Wire in usePuzzle (src/hooks/usePuzzle.ts)
- Create the ValidateMoveFn based on settings.engineEnabled + stockfish readiness
- Pass it to PuzzleEngine
- Handle VALIDATING phase (board non-interactive)

## Done When
- Both modes use the same async code path
- Engine mode validates via Stockfish mate-in-N analysis
- Engine mode plays Stockfish's best defense as opponent
- Post-failure: user can keep playing, Stockfish responds to explore the position
- Graceful fallback when engine fails to load
- All named types (no inline unions)
- No any types
result:
Refactored PuzzleEngine to always-async with pluggable PuzzleStrategy, created useStockfish hook, and wired everything through usePuzzle.

## Design: Option B (Always-Async Unified Path)
Both solution-based and engine-based validation use the same async code path. Solution mode wraps in Promise.resolve() (~0ms). Engine mode awaits Stockfish analysis (~50-300ms). One code path, consistent phase transitions.

## New types (types/index.ts)
- MoveValidationResult: {isCorrect, opponentMove}
- ValidateMoveFn, GetOpponentMoveFn: async strategy functions
- PuzzleStrategy: {validateMove, getOpponentMove, freePlayBothSides}

## PuzzleEngine refactoring (puzzle-engine.ts)
- loadPuzzle() now takes a PuzzleStrategy
- makeMove() is now async, always passes through VALIDATING phase
- Generation-based abort for stale async results on rapid puzzle changes
- Post-failure behavior determined by strategy:
  - Solution mode (freePlayBothSides: true): user plays both sides, existing behavior preserved
  - Engine mode (freePlayBothSides: false): Stockfish plays opponent's best defense, user plays only their side
- Opponent moves come from validation result or getOpponentMove(), not hardcoded solution index

## useStockfish hook (hooks/useStockfish.ts)
- Manages StockfishEngine lifecycle (init on mount, dispose on unmount)
- Tracks loading/ready/error status
- createEngineStrategy(): creates a PuzzleStrategy that validates via Stockfish mate-in-N analysis and uses engine's bestmove for opponent
- Validation logic: after user's move, opponent sees negative mate score → user's move is correct

## usePuzzle updates (hooks/usePuzzle.ts)
- Creates appropriate strategy based on settings.engineEnabled + stockfish.status
- Engine enabled + ready → engine strategy (Stockfish validation + defense)
- Engine disabled or not ready → solution strategy (compare to solution[], user plays both sides after failure)
- Exposes engineStatus/engineError for UI

## Verification
- tsc --noEmit: clean (zero errors)
- 102 tests passing (19 stockfish, 23 chess, 29 puzzles, 15 persistence, 16 timer)

name: Core puzzle state machine and game logic
description:
Implement the central game loop: state machine, puzzle lifecycle, move processing, and timer.

## What
Build the usePuzzle hook that orchestrates the entire puzzle experience — loading puzzles, managing the state machine (LOADING → PLAYING → VALIDATING → OPPONENT_TURN → COMPLETE), processing moves through validation, and tracking solve time.

## Why
This is the brain of the app. It connects the data layer, engine, and UI by managing all state transitions and game rules. Both engine-enabled and engine-disabled modes need to work.

## Implementation

### 1. State Machine (within usePuzzle hook)
States and transitions per spec:
- LOADING: Fetch puzzle by ID, parse FEN, determine side to move → PLAYING
- PLAYING: User's turn, timer running. On user move → VALIDATING
- VALIDATING: Engine analyzing (or solution lookup). Three outcomes:
  - Valid + checkmate → COMPLETE (success if no prior failures)
  - Valid + not mate → OPPONENT_TURN
  - Invalid → back to PLAYING (puzzle marked failed, user can keep exploring)
- OPPONENT_TURN: Engine plays best defense, animate move → PLAYING
- COMPLETE: Checkmate delivered. Show result, stop timer. On 'Next' → LOADING

### 2. usePuzzle Hook (src/hooks/usePuzzle.ts)
- Inputs: puzzle data, stockfish hook, localStorage hook
- State: gamePhase, chess.js instance, moveHistory[], isFailed, currentFEN
- Actions:
  - loadPuzzle(id): reset board, parse FEN, set orientation
  - makeMove(from, to, promotion?): process user move through validation
  - nextPuzzle(): advance currentPuzzleId, save state, load next
- Move history tracking: record each {userMove, opponentMove} pair with annotations
  - Correct moves shown in green (or default)
  - Wrong moves shown in red with strikethrough (per states screenshots)

### 3. Engine-Disabled Fallback Mode
- Validate user's first move against the 'moves' field from JSON
- Auto-play opponent responses from the solution sequence
- Less flexible but works offline/low-power devices
- parseMove() to convert 'f6-g7' format

### 4. Timer (src/hooks/useTimer.ts)
- Starts when puzzle enters PLAYING state
- Pauses during VALIDATING and OPPONENT_TURN (or keeps running — spec says stops on checkmate)
- Stops on COMPLETE
- Returns elapsed time in ms, formatted as MM:SS
- Persisted to PuzzleState.timeMs on completion

### 5. chess.js Integration (src/lib/chess.ts)
- Wrapper utilities around chess.js
- loadFen(fen): create Chess instance from FEN
- makeMove(chess, move): apply move, return new FEN
- isCheckmate(chess): check game end state
- getLegalMoves(chess): for Chessground legal move highlighting
- getSideToMove(fen): extract from FEN string

## Done When
- Full puzzle lifecycle works: load → play moves → checkmate → next
- Engine-enabled mode: validates via Stockfish depth analysis
- Engine-disabled mode: validates against stored solution
- Incorrect moves mark puzzle as failed but allow continued play
- Timer tracks solve time accurately
- State persists to localStorage on completion
- Move history records all moves with correct/incorrect annotations
result: Core puzzle state machine and game logic complete. PuzzleTimer class for timing, PuzzleEngine class for state machine (loading/playing/opponent_turn/complete), usePuzzle hook integrating engine + timer + persistence. Engine-disabled fallback validates against stored solutions. Full App.tsx integration with dark theme. 84 tests, tsc clean, production build clean.

name: chess.js wrapper utilities and tests
description:
Create src/lib/chess.ts with pure helper functions wrapping chess.js, plus comprehensive tests.

## What
A thin, well-typed wrapper around chess.js that provides the exact interfaces needed by Board.tsx and usePuzzle.ts. All functions are pure (take chess instance or FEN, return value) so they're trivially testable.

## Functions

### loadFen(fen: string): Chess
- Create and return a chess.js Chess instance from FEN
- Throws on invalid FEN

### makeMove(chess: Chess, move: { from: string; to: string; promotion?: string }): string | null
- Apply move to chess instance
- Returns SAN notation of the move (e.g., "Qxg7+") or null if illegal
- Mutates the chess instance (chess.js is stateful)

### getLegalDests(chess: Chess): Map<string, string[]>
- Return legal moves in Chessground's dests format: Map<Square, Square[]>
- e.g., Map { "e2" => ["e3", "e4"], "g1" => ["f3", "h3"] }
- Used directly by Chessground's movable.dests config

### isCheckmate(chess: Chess): boolean
- Returns chess.isCheckmate()

### isCheck(chess: Chess): boolean
- Returns chess.isCheck()

### isDraw(chess: Chess): boolean
- Returns chess.isDraw()

### moveToSan(chess: Chess, move: { from: string; to: string; promotion?: string }): string | null
- Convert a move to SAN notation WITHOUT applying it
- Uses chess.js verbose moves to find matching SAN
- Returns null if move is illegal

### getSideToMove(chess: Chess): "w" | "b"
- Returns whose turn it is from the chess instance

### fenToColor(fen: string): "white" | "black"
- Extract active color from FEN string (the second field)
- Returns "white" or "black" for Chessground orientation

## Tests (src/lib/__tests__/chess.test.ts)
- loadFen with valid/invalid FEN
- getLegalDests returns correct map for known positions
- makeMove applies legal moves, returns SAN
- makeMove returns null for illegal moves
- isCheckmate detects mate positions
- isCheck detects check positions
- fenToColor extracts correct color
- Promotion moves work correctly

## Done When
- All functions compile with strict TypeScript (no any)
- Tests pass for all functions
- getLegalDests output is compatible with Chessground dests format
result: Created src/lib/chess.ts with ChessGame class wrapping chess.js. Getters: fen, sideToMove, orientation, turnColor, isCheckmate, isCheck, isDraw, isGameOver. Methods: getLegalDests() returns Chessground-compatible Map with promotion dedup, makeMove(from, to, promotion?) applies move and returns SAN or null, moveToSan() returns SAN without mutation, clone() for deep copy. 24 tests passing covering constructor, legal/illegal moves, check/mate detection, dests computation, promotion handling, cloning. TypeScript strict clean, no any types.

name: Chess board component (Chessground)
description:
Build the Board component wrapping Lichess Chessground for rendering, interaction, and animation.

## What
Create the Board.tsx component that integrates @lichess-org/chessground — the same chess UI used by Lichess in production. This handles all visual board rendering, piece drag/drop, click-to-move, legal move indicators, and animated piece movement for opponent responses.

## Why
Chessground is the visual heart of the app. It needs to correctly reflect game state, respond to user input, auto-orient based on who's playing, and animate opponent moves smoothly.

## Implementation

### 1. Board Component (src/components/Board.tsx)
- Mount Chessground instance into a container div
- Configure with:
  - fen: current position
  - orientation: 'white' or 'black' based on puzzle's 'first' field
  - turnColor: whose turn it is
  - movable: { free: false, color: side to move, dests: legal moves map }
  - draggable: { enabled: true }
  - animation: { enabled: true, duration: 200 }
- Event handlers:
  - onMove(orig, dest): callback to usePuzzle.makeMove()
  - Handle promotion: detect pawn reaching last rank, default to queen (or show picker)
- Update Chessground config reactively when FEN/state changes
- Cleanup on unmount (cg.destroy())

### 2. Legal Move Highlighting
- Compute legal moves from chess.js: chess.moves({ verbose: true })
- Convert to Chessground dests format: Map<Square, Square[]>
- Update dests on each position change
- Disable interaction during VALIDATING and OPPONENT_TURN phases

### 3. Opponent Move Animation
- When engine returns opponent move, apply to Chessground with animation
- Use cg.move(from, to) for animated piece movement
- Brief delay (~300ms) before opponent moves for natural feel

name: Chessground Board component
description:
Create src/components/Board.tsx — a React component wrapping @lichess-org/chessground.

## What
The visual chess board. Accepts props for position, orientation, legal moves, and move callbacks. Handles Chessground lifecycle (create, update, destroy) and imports required CSS.

## Props Interface

```typescript
interface BoardProps {
  fen: string;
  orientation: "white" | "black";
  turnColor: "white" | "black";
  dests: Map<string, string[]>;          // from getLegalDests()
  interactive: boolean;                   // false during validating/opponent_turn
  lastMove?: [string, string];           // highlight last move [from, to]
  onMove: (from: string, to: string, promotion?: string) => void;
}
```

## Implementation

### 1. Chessground Lifecycle
- Use useRef for the container div and the Chessground API instance
- Create Chessground in useEffect on mount, destroy on unmount
- Update config reactively when props change (useEffect with deps)
- Key Chessground config:
  - fen, orientation, turnColor
  - movable: { free: false, color: turnColor (only when interactive), dests }
  - draggable: { enabled: interactive }
  - animation: { enabled: true, duration: 200 }
  - lastMove (highlight squares)
  - events: { move: onMove callback }

### 2. Promotion Handling
- Detect when a pawn reaches the last rank (rank 8 for white, rank 1 for black)
- Auto-promote to queen (simplest, correct for 99% of mate puzzles)
- Pass promotion piece through onMove callback

### 3. CSS
- Import chessground base CSS: @lichess-org/chessground/assets/chessground.base.css
- Import a board theme and piece set (brown board + standard pieces)
- Board container: square aspect ratio, responsive width
- Add a CSS class for the board border (will be used for feedback glow states later)

### 4. Responsive Sizing
- Desktop: max-width ~600px
- Mobile: 100% width minus padding
- The board is always square (aspect-ratio: 1)
- Coordinates visible (a-h, 1-8) — Chessground has built-in coordinate support

### 5. Opponent Move Animation
- When fen changes and lastMove is set, Chessground animates the piece
- No special code needed — Chessground handles this via config diffing

## Done When
- Board renders a FEN position correctly
- Pieces are draggable when interactive=true
- Legal move dots appear on piece selection
- onMove fires with correct from/to/promotion
- Board auto-orients (white/black at bottom)
- Opponent moves animate smoothly when fen + lastMove update
- Board is not interactive when interactive=false
- Responsive sizing works
- No console errors or warnings
result: Created src/components/Board.tsx wrapping @lichess-org/chessground. Props: fen, orientation, turnColor, dests (Map<string, string[]>), interactive, lastMove, check, onMove callback. Uses useRef for Chessground lifecycle (create on mount, set() on prop changes, destroy on cleanup). Imports all three Chessground CSS files (base, brown board, cburnett pieces). Coordinates enabled. Promotion handled by PuzzleEngine. Animation at 200ms. TypeScript strict clean.
